About Us

Helping Agencies & Companies become ADA compliant and maintain WCAG/508 Status.

Kaffeinated Kodemonkey is an Accessibility Agency

Our A11y Developers are DHS Certified Trusted Testers and use the trusted tester process. Paired with an A11y Platform, empower your IT teams to seamlessly add accessibility to their workflow.

Our A11y Developer also follow POUR web design, for an A11y-First approach in creating products that meet WCAG/508 requirements.

  • Perceivable - Users must be able to perceive the information being presented
  • Operable - Users must be able to operate the interface
  • Understandable - Users must be able to understand information & operations
  • Robust - Users must be able to access the content as technologies advances

This approach can improve productivity, ROI, saves time and money, and help ward off potential lawsuits when accessibility is include from the start.

As the owner of Kaffeinated Kodemonkey, I am devoted to helping businesses meet WCAG and Section 508 criteia. Out Accessibility Developers are DHS Certified Trusted Testers and use the Trusted Tester process.

With a background in the corporate and startup sectors, as a front-end developer, the owner picked up Web Accessibility along the way, assisted in the development of technical documents, and education of the staff on the importance of accessibility on the website.

Kaffeinated Kodemonkey grew into an accessibility agency offering VPAT completion, Accessibility Audits, and WCAG/508 Evaluations.

Learn More

Complete A11y for your business

Kaffeinated Kodemonkey is your SME in Accessibility. Our team ensures your digital products are accessible to everyone equally.

Government entities must include a VPAT (AKA - Accessibility compliance Report) in their RFP processes. Furthermore, private businesses are getting sued for inaccessible digital experiences. Releasing inaccessible; software or digital products leaves the company vulnerable to lawsuits that could cost your company more money in the long run.


Check out our services below or Talk to a A11y Developer Today!

Frequently Asked Questions

  • Can web accessibility improve my SEO?

    If you are on a budget and need to choose between marketing or accessibility, take accessibility every time.

    When a product includes accessibility in its design, it naturally increases on-site/on-page SEO allowing the web spiders to index the product accurately. Think of it like this; search engines and web spiders are deaf and blind and need all the help they can in correcting listing and displaying results

    When images are labeled, they get listed in google images and link back to your site. Thus, increasing the visibility of your site. Links offer another source when they are labeled and tiled correctly, which can increase accurate and credible visitors and possible sales..

    Furthermore, accessibility adds needed information to the website that helps search engines display search results that accurately match the search request.

  • Why you should add accessibility now and not later?

    If your product is not accessible when you release it, you risk a lawsuit. The judge does not care if you "plan" to make it accessible later. The judge may give you some leeway, but that "plan" just became right now.

    Not only are you out of legal fees, but also the cost of hiring an accessibility developer and time to remedy accessibility issues. If you have an in-house dev team, you may be able to save some cost, yet you are still out of legal fees. If you do not have an in-house dev team, you are out the cost of legal fees plus the additional cost of a developer to work with the accessibility developer.

    In either case, hiring an accessibility developer from the beginning and including accessibility in the product will save time, money, and hassle.

  • Why Accessibility is important

    There are at least three reasons that might motivate a company to create accessible web content:

    1) To improve the lives of people with disabilities (human-centered motivations)
    2) To capitalize on a wider audience or consumer base (marketing or economic-centered motivations)
    3) To avoid lawsuits and/or bad press (public relations and punishment-centered motivations)


    A11y-driven websites accomplish these goals when people are at the center of the process.

    The Kaffeinated Kodemonkey team strives to use the POUR principles set forth by the WCAG:

    Perceivable - Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive. This means that users must be able to perceive the information being presented (it can't be invisible to all of their senses)

    Operable - User interface components and navigation must be operable. This means that users must be able to operate the interface (the interface cannot require interaction that a user cannot perform)

    Understandable - Information and the operation of the user interface must be understandable. This means that users must be able to understand the information as well as the operation of the user interface (the content or operation cannot be beyond their understanding)

    Robust - Content must be robust enough that it can be interpreted reliably by a wide variety of user agents, including assistive technologies. This means that users must be able to access the content as technologies advance (as technologies and user agents evolve, the content should remain accessible). Those who are simply trying to avoid lawsuits realize must consider and address people with disabilities within their targeted audience.

  • Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

    Section 508 is a set of standards that requires Federal agencies to make ICT accessible to employees and members of the public with disabilities; the same experience as employees and members of the public without disabilities.

    In 1998, Congress amended the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 requiring Federal agencies to make electronic documents accessible to people with disabilities. Section 508 applies to all Federal agencies when it pertains to electronic and information technology. Government agencies must give disabled employees and members of the public access to the same or comparable information as they do others.

    The U.S. Access Board is responsible for developing accessibility standards that govern Federal procurement practices. January 2017, they issued a final rule that updated accessibility requirements for section 508 and refreshed guidelines to Section 255.

    The refresh reorganized Section 508 Standards and Section 255 Guidelines in response to market trends and innovations in technology. The refresh also harmonized these requirements with other guidelines and standards both in the U.S. and abroad, including standards issued by the European Commission, and W3C guidelines know as WCAG.
